original_data.question: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening fatigue for 6 months. During this time, he has also had shortness of breath and palpitations on exertion. He has noticed blood in his stools on three separate occasions in the past 4 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and end-stage renal disease. He drinks two to four beers daily. He does not smoke. His pulse is 95/min and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. The abdomen is soft with no organomegaly. Rectal examination is unremarkable. His hemoglobin concentration is 7.2 g/dL, hematocrit is 32%, and mean corpuscular volume is 68 Î¼m3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's bleeding?

options.A: Inflammation in an outpouching of the colonic wall
options.C: Chronic mucosal and submucosal inflammation of the colon
options.D: Arteriovenous malformation in the colonic wall

model_response:
The patient has diverticulosis, which is the accumulation of many small, walled-off perforations in the colonic wall. Diverticulosis is common in the elderly, and most often affects the sigmoid colon. Bleeding is the most common complication of diverticulosis. Diverticula are thought to develop as a result of high intraluminal pressures, which push the mucosa and submucosa through vascular entry points in the colonic wall. The other choices are not complications of diverticulosis.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Height greater than two standard deviations below the mean of the appropriate reference population for the age and sex of the individual.
The air that is inhaled and exhaled during respiration.
An unpleasant sensation of irregular and/or forceful beating of the heart.
Physical or mental energy; hard work.
The body fluid that circulates in the vascular system (BLOOD VESSELS). Whole blood includes PLASMA and BLOOD CELLS.
Excrement from the INTESTINES, containing unabsorbed solids, waste products, secretions, and BACTERIA of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.
Independent; not united or joint.
Not occurring regularly or at short intervals.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.

A type of diabetes mellitus that is characterized by insulin resistance or desensitization and increased blood glucose levels. This is a chronic disease that can develop gradually over the life of a patient and can be linked to both environmental factors and heredity.

The end-stage of CHRONIC RENAL INSUFFICIENCY. It is characterized by the severe irreversible kidney damage (as measured by the level of PROTEINURIA) and the reduction in GLOMERULAR FILTRATION RATE to less than 15 ml per min (Kidney Foundation: Kidney Disease Outcome Quality Initiative, 2002). These patients generally require HEMODIALYSIS or KIDNEY TRANSPLANTATION.
A single serving of a beverage; any liquid suitable for drinking.
An alcoholic beverage usually made from malted cereal grain (as barley), flavored with hops, and brewed by slow fermentation.
Occurring or done each day.
Visible gaseous suspension of carbon and other particulate matter emitted from burning substances.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A clinical manifestation consisting of an unnatural paleness of the skin.
The mucous membrane that covers the posterior surface of the eyelids and the anterior pericorneal surface of the eyeball.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Lacking in hardness relatively or comparatively.
An abnormal enlargement of an organ, particularly an organ of the abdominal cavity.

The mean cell hemoglobin concentration (MCHC), which is the average concentration of hemoglobin in a given volume of blood. The MCHC is a calculated value derived from the measurement of hemoglobin and the hematocrit.

The volume of packed RED BLOOD CELLS in a blood specimen. The volume is measured by centrifugation in a tube with graduated markings, or with automated blood cell counters. It is an indicator of erythrocyte status in disease. For example, ANEMIA shows a low value; POLYCYTHEMIA, a high value.
MCV equals HEMATOCRIT divided by ERYTHROCYTE COUNT.
